fields.Detailed Progress old:
Jun 24: Team formed. Early focus on validating credit scoring problem with banks and consumers.

Aug 4: 59 bank contacts made, 1 showing interest. Product development: consumer app launch targeted this month with goal of 1,000 early users. Incorporation not yet completed, blocking paid pilots.

Aug 8: Open banking integration path established. Consumer app launched this weekend. 74 bank executives contacted; 2 meetings lined up. 3 LOIs signed.

Aug 11: Beta app launched with Tink (Visa) integration. 2 bank meetings secured. Fintech partner interested in year-long paid pilot regardless of user base. Identified Microbank (CaixaBank subsidiary) as key strategic target. Outreach expanded to 118 additional risk managers.

Aug 15: User app live, but traction metrics missing from pitch. Market size and AI benefits to banks not clearly presented.

Aug 18: Technical progress: app deployed on AWS, open banking integration functioning. 3 LOIs still active, aiming for 5. Hottest lead: Austrian online bank via software partner. Preparing fintech pilot meeting in Barcelona.

Aug 22: First LOI converted to paid pilot (‚Ç¨1.5K, potential to scale into ‚Ç¨50K ARR). Continuing discussions with other banks. Meeting scheduled with St√©phane Boghossian to refine user acquisition strategy.

Aug 25: Cofounder conflict emerged (communication breakdown, unclear roles). Urgent need for process fixes before IC.

Aug 29: 1 paid pilot signed, negotiating 2nd pilot. Feedback from IC prep: need to show clear differentiation from existing bank algorithms and a solid customer acquisition plan.
fields.Maxime's Comment:

CONS:
Internal team issues (they solicited Pioneers to resolve a team issue)
Inexistant traction in their edge
Hard market: High regulations in market - long time to market
GDPR potential issues

fields.Detailed Progress:
üìÖ Progress Timeline

üë• Jun 23 ‚Äì Team Formation

Zac (COO), Jules (CEO), Tomas (CTO just decided to leave on September 3!)


üõ†Ô∏è Aug 5 ‚Äì Office Hours

- Customer discovery: ~100 cold calls, 15 logistics companies engaged (5 large, 10 SMEs)

- Prospects: FM Logistic, Andros, XPO, Group Rota

- 2 staffing agencies committed as contract partners

- Marketplace model validated with 50% margin on full-service (supply + demand)

- Goal: first transactions by end of month


üé§ Aug 8 ‚Äì Pitch

- Position: Unified database for blue-collar workers

- MVP: predicting no-shows + real-time worker replacement

- Case study: logistics company with 30% no-shows costing ‚Ç¨2M/year


üé§ Aug 15 ‚Äì Pitch

- Reframed as AI hiring system for staffing agencies

- Value: reducing placement time from days ‚Üí minutes with sourcing + matching automation

- Progress: traction in France, but struggling in US (cold calls harder)

- Feedback: solution too broad, problem statement generic, urged to focus on France first

- Target: design partners next week, paying customers by end of summer


üé§ Aug 22 ‚Äì Pitch

- Solution: AI conversational agent messaging workers in parallel, automating agency workflows

- Market: ‚Ç¨200B staffing, focusing on ‚Ç¨22B temp staffing segment

- Progress: 2 design partners signed, MVP ready, aiming for 2 more + first paying customers

- Feedback: clarify terminology (‚Äútalent pool‚Äù vs AI agent)


üé§ Aug 29 ‚Äì Pitch

- Position: AI recruiter automating candidate search/outreach (4 hours ‚Üí minutes)

- Traction: new design partner signed, 25 customers contacted, pipeline of 1000 agencies identified

Feedback (Salomon):
‚Ä¢ Strong presentation
‚Ä¢ Market is crowded ‚Üí stronger traction needed before VC funding

üé§ Sep 8 ‚Äì Pre-IC

- Traction: 4 design partners signed, ‚Ç¨38k revenue pipeline

- Market: ‚Ç¨200B global staffing, ‚Ç¨42B in France

- Model: Hybrid approach (AI tool + database ownership + full agency services)

- Strategy: focus on small agency partnerships to gain traction, validate in Europe before US expansion

- Vision: long-term plan to own worker database and provide end-to-end staffing solutions

Jun 23: Team formed. Early team changes ‚Äî Gabriel left, Arthur joined from another team. Current structure: Zac (CEO/sales), Tomas (CTO ‚Äì PhD ML), Arthur (product), Jules (CEO role testing). Still aligning on roles, no equity agreements yet. Strong early impression but later flagged for lack of quantified customer learnings.

Aug 5: Office hours. Customer discovery: ~100 cold calls, 15 logistics companies engaged (5 large, 10 SMEs). Prospects include FM Logistic, Andros, XPO, Group Rota. Two staffing agencies committed as contract partners. Marketplace model with 50% margin on full-service (supply + demand) validated. Goal: first transactions by end of month. YC application submitted.

Aug 8: Pitch. Positioned as unified database for blue-collar workers. MVP: predicting no-shows and real-time worker replacement. Highlighted logistics case study (30% no-shows costing ‚Ç¨2M/year). US market focus announced (San Francisco launch).

Aug 15: Pitch. Reframed as AI hiring system for staffing agencies. Value: reducing placement time from days to minutes by automating sourcing and matching. Progress: traction in France, struggling to break into US (harder cold calling). Feedback: solution too broad, problem statement generic, urged to focus on France first. Target: design partners next week, paying customers by end of summer.

Aug 22: Pitch. Team reframed as Zac (4 years logistics/hiring), Jules (VC/startup), plus technical builder. Solution: AI conversational agent messaging workers in parallel, automating agency workflows. Market: ‚Ç¨200B staffing, targeting ‚Ç¨22B temp staffing. Progress: 2 design partners signed, MVP ready, aiming for 2 more + first paying customers. Feedback: clarify terminology (‚Äútalent pool‚Äù vs AI agent).

Aug 29: Pitch. Positioned as AI recruiter automating candidate search/outreach (4 hours ‚Üí minutes). Traction: new design partner signed, 25 potential customers contacted, pipeline of 1000 agencies identified. Feedback from Salomon: good presentation, but crowded market ‚Äî will need stronger traction before VC funding; offered introductions to Xfiner (acquired by Randstad).
fields.Main SU 2025 (2): Gabriel Duciel, Jules Ferrer, Zaccarie Morel
fields.Maxime's Comment:
PROS:

TEAM:
The 2 founders (Zack and Jules) have complementary personalities and are very aligned in their vision and way of working. 
They also present well and are outspoken. 
Zac has strong experience with Blue-collar workers in his previous experience. (he's the ex-COO of Bold, and founder of La Tourn√©e)

EXECUTION:
During the program they showed a good capacity to question themselves and their positioning. (They have pivoted on their solution 3-4 times)
Within the program: they closed a design partnership with a big interim company with a annual contract value of 25k EUR.

CONS:

TEAM:
Lost 2 CTO -cofounders during the program, which is an "orange" flag in their capacity to attract and keep strong talent.

EXECUTION:
Pivoted too many times which shows a lack of market clarity which resulted in not shipping any product during the program.

MARKET:
Their new positioning (Full-stack AI-agency play) might hinder their chances of subsequent VC funding due to challenging scalability.

fields.Detailed Progress old:
Jul 17: Team formed. Leon brings 5 years GovTech experience (previous VC-backed startup). Identified opportunity in sales intelligence for tech companies targeting German public sector. Initial validation: 15 customer interviews, focus narrowed to foreign tech companies (AWS, Palo Alto, CrowdStrike) with small German public sector teams.

Aug 6: Office hours. Demo prepared for CrowdStrike, 3‚Äì4 hot leads identified. Recommendation: charge ‚Ç¨200‚Äì500 for design partnerships to ensure commitment. Market assessment: GovTech hard but moat-building if cracked. Execution risk: little visible traction yet.

Aug 8: Pitch. Positioned as AI-enabled Bloomberg Terminal for procurement. Demo functional, data extraction working. First paid LOI secured (‚Ç¨250/month), with 3 more pilots in pipeline.

Aug 15: Pitch. Signed first paid pilot (‚Ç¨300 for 6 weeks) + 2 additional LOIs. AWS identified as major account (50‚Äì60 person public sector team). Feedback: must show market size more clearly, sharpen solution definition, and craft compelling win stories.

Aug 22: Pitch. Refined to public sector sales intelligence platform. Market framed as 10,000 companies selling to German government (‚Ç¨200M), expandable to ‚Ç¨105B Europe. Progress: 2 LOIs pending, more demos ongoing. Feedback: slides too focused on problem (half presentation), team‚Äôs data-processing expertise underplayed, market sizing visuals confusing.

Aug 29: Pitch. Completed paid pilot with CrowdStrike. Positioned as entity-profiling and early signal detection tool for public sector sales. Upcoming industry fair (20k visitors) seen as major opportunity. Feedback from Salomon: strong concept, but needs clearer GTM strategy, stronger government navigation expertise, and focus on high ACV contracts (limited number of customers).
fields.Maxime's Comment:
PROS:

TEAM:
The CEO has a strong and rare sector knowledge that can be a strong defensibility point. Leon (CEO) worked for the German government as a Parlimentary Assistant and as an associate in a German Federal Office.  

EXECUTION:
The team has gotten their first paid pilot in mid-August (notoriously known to be hard) with entreprise client (Crowdstrike).
They've already shipped first version of the product within 1 month of building. 

CONS:

TEAM:
The CEO has an introvert personality and is not the most charismatic, which might affect their capacity to close deals.

MARKET:
The market complexity:
- Country-specific - hard for scaling (However, the data sources are European).
- Can be considered niche.

fields.Detailed Progress old:
Jul 25: Team formed (Pierre ‚Äì Google B2B sales, Pascal ‚Äì Google product strategy). Focus: AI nutrition/chatbot app for fitness and nutrition coaching, using B2B2C partnerships with gyms/pharmacies.

Aug 4: Early traction with major players: Fitness Park (1M members, launch Sept/Oct), Groupe Mirage (26 Paris gyms acquired), Decathlon (contact with CMO, exploring freemium model). Goal: deploy in 500 Fitness Park gyms by Jan 2026, starting with 50‚Äì100 pilot gyms. Alpha app ready with nutrition tracking, macro updates, and personalized coaching; beta launch targeted for Sept. Risks flagged around dependency on external development agency (5% equity deal).

Aug 8: Pitch. Positioned as 24/7 nutritional chatbot. Market validation: 126K Twitter views, influencer support. Development challenges: GPT-4 API vs ChatGPT speed issues. B2B traction: meetings with Fitness Park, Decathlon, Newness, Basic Fit, Episode, and Alan (insurance) for wellness partnership. Launch target: mid-Sept (uncertain for pre-IC).

Aug 11: Office hours. Roadmap created for 0‚Äì3 months with sales projections. Product: base validated, but UX not yet commercial. Discussed demo dilemma (show infra vs mock-ups). Equity deal with agency considered too risky; alternatives identified (BPI grants, angels, freelancers). Target: ‚Ç¨80‚Äì100k to fund first version without long-term equity loss.

Aug 15: Pitch. Positioned as AI nutrition companion with B2B2C via gyms/pharmacies. 4 soft partnership commitments secured. MVP due end of August, beta Sept. Feedback: strong potential but must avoid risky agency equity deal.

Aug 22: Pitch. Problem framed as global weight-loss failure rates (95%). Market: ‚Ç¨5B nutrition apps, ‚Ç¨15B fitness/wellness. Progress: engaged top 5 gym networks covering 40% of market, alpha version releasing end of week. Feedback: too much time on problem/solution, needs more focus on traction and distribution.

Aug 29: Pitch. Progress: 7 gym networks engaged, 2 agreed to commercialization rollout. Market approach: target 75% of French gym-goers (~‚Ç¨2.5‚Äì5M ARR potential). Feedback from Salomon: hot market, but crowded. Need proof of gym acquisition execution and viral loops before IC.
fields.Maxime's Comment:
PROS:

TEAM:
Quality team background (ex-Google employees having worked on consumer-facing products)
Charismatic CEO

TRACTION:
Good Sales traction and momentum: Within 6 weeks, they managed to be in advanced discussions with 6-7 gym networks representing +/- 4.5m users (thereof one commitment from BasicFit) and 2 influencers with +4m users.

CONS:

TEAM:
CTO is not full-stack - doesn't ship very fast which resulted in first launch only after 2 months of developing (Product execution risk).

MARKET:
Low potential defensibility (although working on blood sampling).
Red Ocean market with many players.

üìÖ Progress Timeline

‚Ä¢ ‚Ç¨70/seat subscription

- Delivers 20‚Äì30 warm leads/month with 30%+ reply rates (3x industry avg)

fields.Detailed Progress old:
Jun 18: Team formed. Early energy strong, good complementarity (Connor ‚Äì backend, Jonathan ‚Äì frontend, Cl√©ment ‚Äì CRO, St√©phane ‚Äì CEO). Started in HR process optimization, but after 100+ customer interviews pivoted toward hiring/sourcing solutions. Initial traction slowed during July (personal factors + pivot).

Aug 5: Office hours. Pivoted to hiring specialization. Introduced two pricing models (‚Ç¨300 2-week sprint with ‚Ç¨200 deposit; ‚Ç¨70/seat subscription). Goal: 10 paying customers pre-product. Early interest from HubSpot, Sorare, Salesforce, Klaviyo. No paying clients yet. Targeting CEOs directly instead of HR (decision-making power + budget).

Aug 8: Pitch. Positioned as automated headhunting via LinkedIn founder networks. Early proof: Sorare engaged, payment pending; more clients expected post-vacation. MVP delivered manually while building tech. Goal: 500 outreach/week, 20 meetings, 10 new clients.

Aug 15: Pitch. Reported first 2 paying customers (‚Ç¨1K/year each). Conversion funnel example: 20 requests ‚Üí 14 accepts ‚Üí 4 replies ‚Üí 1 hire. Feedback: avoid comparisons with small automation tools (Waalaxy, PhantomBuster), instead show bigger vision for CEO recruiting transformation. Target: 140 customers by cohort end.

Aug 22: Pitch. Refined solution: ‚ÄúAlways-on recruiting OS‚Äù for Series A/B founders, providing 20‚Äì30 warm leads monthly with 30%+ reply rates (3x industry). MVP built; migration of early clients to product scheduled. Market framed as ‚Ç¨1.5‚Äì2M ARR with 100 clients. Feedback: tagline too vague (‚Äúrecruiting OS‚Äù), problem section too long, solution slide should show concrete product mechanics.

Aug 29: Pitch. Progress: 5 paying customers, ‚Ç¨6K ARR. MVP deployed as LinkedIn AI agent generating 160 conversations/month, 65% reply rate, Slack integration for workflow. Pricing: ‚Ç¨199/month. Target: ‚Ç¨190K ARR by mid-Sept. Feedback from Salomon: strong website, but needs demo video; must focus on retention/churn and HR tool integrations (e.g. Personio, HiBob) to be credible at scale.
fields.Maxime's Comment:
PROS:

TEAM:
CEO is a repeat-entrepreneur: Stephane has launched several companies with respectable outcomes (million+ revenues and several small exits)
They have a complimentary team.

EXECUTION:
They pivoted several times in the HR space and have now found a somewhat convincing/differentiated entry point.
Strong sales capacity: within 2 months they managed to sign several "high-profile" tech scaleups already such as Sorare and Timeleft.

CONS:

TEAM:
- CEO just had a baby and is based is now based in Biarritz, they will be working remotely half of the time.
- Team is too big for an early stage company (4 members including a head of Sales/CSO), CEO seems to act sometimes as a manager rather than a founder.

MARKET:
- HR market is notoriously hard as it's a red ocean.

Aug 5: Office hours. Team targeting 3 more LOIs by IC. Quantified outreach process introduced (daily outreach funnel tracking). Public LinkedIn posting approved to build awareness in developer communities. Product MVP targeted for first pilots.

Aug 8: Friday pitch positioned Orchly as AI for incident alert prioritization. Progress: 2 LOIs converting into pilots, first version planned for Aug 15. Feedback: strong problem validation but need startup case studies before selling into enterprise.

Aug 12: Office hours. Pilot customer engagement inconsistent (slow responses). Product launch set for Aug 15 ‚Äî plan to release even if incomplete. Pipeline weaker than expected; demo quality too basic. Team launching multi-platform outreach, planning automated campaigns. Validation remains strong: incident remediation pain clearly resonates.

Aug 15: Pitch. 5,000-lead cold email campaign launched. MVP delayed to Aug 18 after customer feedback. Progress with design partners but presentation flagged as low-energy and unfocused. Feedback: must streamline GTM strategy and avoid showing zero metrics.

Aug 19: Deck review session. Major changes required: clarify title (‚ÄúHelping developers resolve incidents faster‚Äù), simplify problem slide with big numbers, avoid technical jargon like MTTR. Team slide needs credibility boost (specific roles, real incident savings, ‚Ç¨350k in 20 min Zalando example). Design cleanup across slides.

Aug 22: Pitch. Progress: 2 active customers, MVP nearly ready. Team presenting stronger with use case examples. Still too many unproven GTM channels. Problem slide text-heavy. Feedback: traction credible but storytelling must highlight ‚Ç¨10M+ savings from past work and 1000+ incidents solved.

Aug 29: Pitch. Progress: 2 signed customers + 1 new Amsterdam client. Team experience: 26+ years, 1000+ incidents solved, ‚Ç¨10M+ revenue saved. Solution framed as AI copilot aggregating monitoring data and generating insights. GTM: starting with startups via CTO network (500+). Feedback from Salomon: problem real but story not ‚Äúsexy‚Äù; must show differentiation vs Monte Carlo earlier.

üé§ Aug 22 ‚Äì Pitch

fields.Detailed Progress old:
Jul 25: Team formed. Zac (founder of Good Legal with 48K users) partnered with Moussa (AI engineer). Initial idea: infrastructure API for AI agents, later pivoted to lawyer-facing tools.

Aug 8: First pitch. Problem framed as legal research chaos (10+ logins, 20+ tabs). Solution: browser-controlling AI agent. Early traction: 54 outreach emails (44% click rate), 1 waitlist signup, 60k lawyer database available. Ambition: build 4 tools/month.

Aug 15: Pitch. Reframed as ‚ÄúStripe for legal research,‚Äù emphasizing infrastructure for AI agents by 2030. Progress: 6 waitlist signups, iterating on landing page. Strong founder credibility noted, but product positioning unclear (prosumer vs infrastructure). Feedback: need sharper articulation of target customer and approach.

Aug 22: Pitch. MVP nearing launch. Positioning still too technical (‚ÄúSERP Firecrawl API‚Äù) and lacked clear lawyer connection. Learning: lawyers want immediate interaction with a UI, not just infrastructure. MVP private beta scheduled for Monday.

Aug 29: Pitch. Progress: 7 tools launched, background credibility with 48K-user Good Legal. Signed design partnership with established legal publisher (founded 1612): ‚Ç¨30k creation fee + ‚Ç¨10k/year maintenance with credit-sharing model. Market framed as ‚Ç¨850B legal tooling space, currently dominated by human effort. Feedback from Salomon: strong pain/solution framing, good vision, but slides need stronger visuals for investor impact.

fields.Detailed Progress old:
Jun 17: Team formed (Maria ‚Äì PhD in AI/NLP, Alex ‚Äì B2B entrepreneur). Targeting large B2B companies struggling with legal approval delays.

Aug 4: Product v1 ~2‚Äì3 weeks from launch. Hitachi pilot nearly ready. Market focus clarified: contract-heavy industrial players (500+ employees, Europe). Sales pipeline built with color-coded stages; first goal set to sign an additional pilot by end of August.

Aug 8: Pitch framed around removing 80% of legal bottlenecks. Alstom demo scheduled; Odoo meeting secured. Strong technical progress, but faced contract history management bug.

Aug 11: Alstom less suitable (public procurement focus). Maria advanced on core feature but still battling bugs. Sales strategy pivot: from angels to direct prospect outreach using ‚Äúadvice-seeking‚Äù approach. Identified SaaS companies as a promising new ICP, building list of 60+ targets. Discussion on stealth mode vs launching basic website. Pipeline: aiming for 3‚Äì4 pilots, 2 minimum acceptable.

Aug 15: Friday pitch emphasized AI solution for repetitive legal reviews. Progress: 1 pilot signed with Hitachi, demo scheduled with Alstom VP Legal, strong interest from Coface & CEVA. Goal: 1 more LOI + 5 new companies contacted. Feedback: go-to-market too broad, unclear on organizational behavior change required.

Aug 18: Deck review for IC prep. Feedback: tagline too vague, problem framing needs specificity (3‚Äì4 week delays in B2B context), slides lacked text hierarchy. Recommendation: start with team slide for credibility. Both Salomon & Bruno will be voting at IC.

Aug 22: Clearer pitch delivered. 50+ interviews since May. ‚Ç¨15K paid pilot signed with Hitachi. Alstom and Odoo discussions ongoing. Feedback: stronger clarity vs previous weeks, but competitor landscape and distribution strategy still missing.

Aug 29: Team presented refined version. Progress: 50+ interviews, ‚Ç¨15K pilot with Hitachi. Ongoing discussions with Alstom, Coface, and CEVA. Salomon feedback: strong pain point identification, but questions on technical integration, reliance on past approvals for high-budget decisions, and ACV pricing justification (‚Ç¨50‚Äì100k).

fields.Detailed Progress old:
Jun 20: Team formed. Vision: AI assistant to automate communication and coordination for short-term rental managers (Airbnb/Booking).

Aug 4: Focus on converting free users to paid. Booking integration causing delays but prioritized for rollout. Lead magnet campaign for past Airbnb testers launched. Cold calls and LinkedIn outreach bringing steady sign-ups. Milestone goal: 1,000 listings by Selection Day.

Aug 8: Pitch positioned Ava as 8x cheaper than manual concierges (‚Ç¨60k/year savings for 40 listings). Progress: partnership with Keynes (smart locks), outreach to larger property managers. Technical blocker: still not live on Booking, slowing growth.

Aug 11: Booking integration release delayed again, blocking paid conversions. Landing page upgraded with video guides and FAQs. Outreach yielding 7 new sign-ups this week (5 from cold calls, 20 from automated campaigns). Learning: engaged clients drive product forward, silent clients often churn. Need automated customer issue-tracking database.

Aug 15: Reported ‚Ç¨650 MRR, targeting ‚Ç¨800 next week. Partnership agreed with Key Nest (hardware lock partner). Clients highly value analytics features. Pitch feedback: missing long-term vision beyond current chatbot and ‚Ç¨25/listing model. Next focus: automate support, stabilize Booking integration, explore UK market.

Aug 22: Strong traction: ‚Ç¨2K MRR, 78% post-demo conversion, zero churn, 5 new clients/week. Signed Flex Living (700 listings, 3-year partner) and other domotics partnerships. Expanded into Italy/Spain. Feedback: highlight zero churn and multi-platform coverage; add market growth data.

Aug 29: Reported 35 customers, 800 listings, ‚Ç¨2K MRR. Solution positioned as AI co-pilot covering communication, reviews, scheduling, and staff coordination across Airbnb, Booking, WhatsApp, calls, and texts. Feedback from Salomon: strong product-market fit and sticky model, but missing roadmap from ‚Ç¨2K MRR to ‚Ç¨100K ARR and competitive landscape.
fields.Maxime's Comment:
PROS:

TEAM:
By far the most hardworking and consistent team (always the earliest team in the office and last to leave).
The only team that share their weekly updates without reminders.
Great synergy - They are aligned on the vision and they get along very well.

EXECUTION:
High shipping velocity: they have launched over 70 features in 3 months after constant contact with customers.
Good traction: they've acquired 45 users, on 750 listings, and 3k MRR in less than 3 months.


CONS:
Complex market to achieve fast growth.
Unclear path to billion dollar business.
